subNodes.conversationText: Ah, greetings once more. [To Vroman.] If you seek the solace of Ilmater after your recent loss, you have come to the right place. You will be glad to know that Manfred's body has been interred.
Thank you, Anselm.  If I so wished, would it be possible for me to see his tomb?
Of course.  You can find the tomb in the crypt down below; here is the key.
May Ilmater continue to bless you and keep you from suffering.  Do you need anything else of me?
Is Ilmater the patron deity of Drawn Swords?

Drawn Swords has no patron deity, though you might say that Ilmater would have that title by default these days.  Before I came here, this chapel had a few small shrines to other deities.  Helm and Tempus were the most popular.

Hamfast's great-uncle, Saern, was a deeply devoted Helmite, and saw Drawn Swords as an admirable place to serve in Helm's name. The peak of a crag is an apt spot for a servant of the Vigilant One, is it not?

The god of war, on the other hand, has always been popular in this region.  After all, the hardy hunters who live in the Backlands often spend half their lives hunting for food and half their lives hunting orcs.
That said, Ilmater has been well-received.  The people of Drawn Swords know suffering.  Winters are hard here.  There is a Backlands saying--"It can't be spring until someone dies."  Harsh, but true.
The chapel offers healing potions and scrolls to those in need. My own powers are quite limited. Would you like to see what we have?
Tell me more of yourself, Brother Anselm.
Me?  I am just a humble priest of Ilmater.  I came to Drawn Swords five years ago from the farming town of Asbravn.
Can you tell me more of Ilmater?
Of course.  He is the Crying God, the protector of those who suffer and the shelter of the weak.  Have you not heard his name before?
Of course.  It is just that I am a cleric of <Deity> myself, and am always interested in hearing other priests' spiritual perspectives.
Ah, wonderful!  It is rare I meet other clerics.

I am an Ilmatari traditionalist, so I am not part of the orthodox church.  This means that while I venerate Ilmater's saints, I believe that it is best for Ilmater's followers to praise him above the acts of the holy martyrs.
Yes, but I was interested in hearing your take on him.

Ilmater teaches us that those who would suffer for their beliefs or to keep others from suffering are the most blessed of all.  Men and women who have suffered greatly for either cause are called saints.
I need nothing at the moment.  Farewell.
I see that Hamfast has passed on my message.  I wanted to extend my thanks for all that you have done and plan to do for Drawn Swords, <FirstName>.
You have already routed two spies from our midst, and infiltrated a camp of the Black Network dangerously close to town.

I would be remiss if I did not seek to show my thanks--take this sickle.  It is magical, and was a gift of my father to me.  He hoped that I would be a farmer and a member of Asbravn's militia, as he was.  Well--I ended up a priest.  I think he'd approve of seeing it in your hands.
Oh, Anselm--A gift from your father?  I couldn't possibly accept.
Do not trouble yourself. My father was a practical man, not a sentimental one. I insist that he would prefer that the sickle be used.

You're welcome.  I have something else for you--news that might have something to do with the turmoil in the region.  For my own reasons, I have not told Danmar or Hamfast.  But Ilmater wills that I should tell you.
An aggressive cult is winning new converts to the east...Ilmater save me!  I--I know little more than this, except that it has gained a large following.
Interesting.  Why are you telling me this, and why did you keep the news from the others?

Honestly?  I did not want the news to spread to the townsfolk.  I know--or, I have heard tales--miracles performed, instant conversions to this new faith...The people of Drawn Swords do not need to worry about such things.
Indeed.  I am surprised that I have not heard news of this cult myself--but I am cut off from my order here.
Were you afraid for their sake or for yours, Anselm?  You are the town's only priest, after all.
<FirstName>!  These are unjust misgivings.  Anselm is benevolent and honorable.
No, it is true: I was afraid for both parties. I remain afraid for both parties.
In any case, the information may be of no use to you, but I thought I would mention it.  Ilmater compelled me to tell you.
What is the nature of the cult?  Who does it worship?
They claim to worship a god named Amaunator--an old solar deity of Netheril, long since dead.  Many are converts from the worship of Lathander, who they say is to die and be reborn as Amaunator.
I see.  Thank you for the information.
Thanks.  This ought to fetch a nice price somewhere.
That's not quite what I was intending, but--
I welcome you back to this humble chapel.  How may I serve?
Is Ilmater the patron deity of Drawn Swords?

Drawn Swords has no patron deity, though you might say that Ilmater would have that title by default these days.  Before I came here, this chapel had a few small shrines to other deities.  Helm and Tempus were the most popular.

Hamfast's great-uncle, Saern, was a deeply devoted Helmite, and saw Drawn Swords as an admirable place to serve in Helm's name. The peak of a crag is an apt spot for a servant of the Vigilant One, is it not?

The god of war, on the other hand, has always been popular in this region.  After all, the hardy hunters who live in the Backlands often spend half their lives hunting for food and half their lives hunting orcs.
That said, Ilmater has been well-received.  The people of Drawn Swords know suffering.  Winters are hard here.  There is a Backlands saying--"It can't be spring until someone dies."  Harsh, but true.
The chapel offers healing potions and scrolls to those in need. My own powers are quite limited. Would you like to see what we have?
Tell me more of yourself, Brother Anselm.
Me?  I am just a humble priest of Ilmater.  I came to Drawn Swords five years ago from the farming town of Asbravn.
Can you tell me more of Ilmater?
Of course.  He is the Crying God, the protector of those who suffer and the shelter of the weak.  Have you not heard his name before?
Of course.  It is just that I am a cleric of <Deity> myself, and am always interested in hearing other priests' spiritual perspectives.
Ah, wonderful!  It is rare I meet other clerics.

I am an Ilmatari traditionalist, so I am not part of the orthodox church.  This means that while I venerate Ilmater's saints, I believe that it is best for Ilmater's followers to praise him above the acts of the holy martyrs.
Yes, but I was interested in hearing your take on him.

Ilmater teaches us that those who would suffer for their beliefs or to keep others from suffering are the most blessed of all.  Men and women who have suffered greatly for either cause are called saints.
Brother Anselm, I have some strange news for you.  Some undead appeared in the crypt.
[Growing pale.] What?! Here? But--how? Where did they come from? Those tombs are sealed and consecrated.
<color=green>[Wisdom] If the zombies are not from the crypt, then some outside force must have brought them there</color>.
If that is the case, then I must find out who or what was involved in their summoning! Thank you for informing me of this.
I could not accept--the church has very little to give an adventurer such as yourself.  Still, I must admit that my strength is in ministry, not in thwarting necromancers and their servants.
I do not need a reward for this.  Even a small force of undead could take a town like Drawn Swords, especially if they are being summoned.  I do this for the good of all.

Ilmater bless you; I accept your offer. It occurs to me that it is only possible that someone who has access to the crypt could possibly have let the zombies in. There are two individuals, besides me, who have keys--my acolytes, Dunne and Obern.
Tell me more of Dunne and Obern.
Both of them are relatively new to Drawn Swords, and to me.  I wrote to my mother church in Asbravn requesting clerical aid here, and they sent them.

They have been here since Flamerule--so about three months.  Their letter of introduction said that they were natives of Sunset Vale, where Asbravn stands. It did cross my mind that it was strange I did not know them, being from Asbravn myself.
Do you think either of them could have been responsible?

Insofar as they are clerics of Ilmater, I think it quite impossible...On the other hand, I am not a complete stranger to the way the world works. Why either of them would be summoning zombies to the crypt is another question altogether.
They lodge in the Sword and Dragon.  Farewell, and try not to let word get out about this.
I do not know Obern or Dunne very well, but if either is hiding something, he is doing a very good job of it. The Knights of the Ruby Rose are uncommonly good at distinguishing foul from fair.
So it seems that Manfred continues to plague me from beyond the grave. After all, he was the only reason we ever went down into that crypt to begin with. [Shaking his head.] Lead on!
That is all the more reason for you not to have to do this on your own.  Believe me, Anselm, when I say that I would be glad to help you.
We can discuss the reward later.  For now, know that I am willing.
On second thought, perhaps this matter belongs in your hands.
Perhaps it does.  I must see this as a challenge--one of the many things we must suffer through for the sake of the good.  In any case, I thank you once again for bringing this to my attention.
Well, I hope that the problem is resolved soon.
I most certainly hope so too, and I thank you once again for bringing this to my attention.
It is possible that the zombies were summoned.  There was an aura of recent necromantic magic about them.
I do not know how they got there.  But they were very real.
Indeed.  I know for a fact that those graves are safe from the ravages of black magic--so it would make sense that those zombies were somehow summoned there.
If that is the case, then I must find out who or what was involved in their summoning! Thank you for telling me.
I could not accept--the church has very little to give an adventurer such as yourself.  Still, I must admit that my strength is in ministry, not in thwarting necromancers and their servants.
I do not need a reward for this.  Even a small force of undead could take a town like Drawn Swords, especially if they are being summoned.  I do this for the good of all.
That is all the more reason for you not to have to do this on your own.  Believe me, Anselm, when I say that I would be glad to help you.
We can discuss the reward later.  For now, know that I am willing.
On second thought, perhaps this matter belongs in your hands.
Yes, it does.  I must see this as a challenge--one of the many things we must suffer through for the sake of the good.  In any case, I thank you once again for bringing this to my attention.
Well, I hope that the problem is resolved soon.
I most certainly hope so too, and I thank you once again for bringing this to my attention.
I agree that it seems very unusual.
I would still be willing to help you investigate those zombies, Anselm.
[Tell Anselm about the fight with Obern, and show him the fragment of the letter you discovered.]

Unbelievable!  Dunne and Obern were spies?!  And this letter--this is the same hand in which their letter of introduction was written!  It stands to reason that my request for aid was intercepted by some enemy of the town.
It does seem that way.  Whoever intercepted your letter to Asbravn sent Dunne and Obern in place of the real clerics.  I am mortified that those two escaped my notice for so long.
Who could they have been working for?
I have no idea.  The Zhentarim, as you know, have been thick in this area lately, so they seem the most likely suspects.
Still, the reason for their being here is murky, and their attempt to conjure zombies to the crypt was not a good strategic move.  Zhents are usually better thinkers.
As <FirstName> explained, Dunne seems to have planted the zombies there on purpose.  We saw him betray Obern and flee.  If Obern was a Zhent, maybe Dunne had other allegiances.
That still does not explain what they were doing here, Vroman.
Indeed.  Well, I thank you for investigating.  I will inform Hamfast immediately, unless you have further questions.
I have no questions--I am simply glad to have helped.
Take this gold--it is not much, but it comes from tithes that were meant to feed and lodge Dunne and Obern over the winter.  I can afford to part with these potions, too.
Will I receive any reward for this task?
What do you think the note means?
Beyond the literal meaning--that they were obviously waiting for someone to arrive--I have no idea.  Perhaps we should be wary of any strange new visitors to Drawn Swords over the next few weeks.
Beyond the literal meaning--that they were obviously waiting for someone to arrive--I have no idea.  Perhaps we should be wary of any strange new visitors to Drawn Swords over the next few weeks.
Hmm--We do not know when this note was written.  It is possible that whoever they were waiting for is already here, or has already come and gone.
In the end, it is good that at least one of the spies has been dealt with.
The chapel offers healing potions and scrolls to those in need. My own powers are quite limited. Would you like to see what we have?
I need nothing at the moment.  Farewell.
